quote.text: I believe there is one Supreme most perfect being. ... I believe He is pleased and delights in the happiness of those He has created; and since without virtue man can have no happiness in this world, I firmly believe He delights to see me virtuous.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin
quote.reference: Articles of Belief and Acts of Religion (1728)

quote.text: Ambition has its disappointments to sour us, but never the good fortune to satisfy us.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Remember that time is money.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: The Faith you mention has doubtless its use in the World. I do not desire to see it diminished, nor would I endeavour to lessen it in any Man. But I wish it were more productive of good Works, than I have generally seen it: I mean real good Works, Works of Kindness, Charity, Mercy, and Publick Spirit; not Holiday-keeping, Sermon-Reading or Hearing; performing Church Ceremonies, or making long Prayers, filled with Flatteries and Compliments, despis’d even by wise Men, and much less capable of pleasing the Deity. The worship of God is a Duty; the hearing and reading of Sermons may be useful; but, if Men rest in Hearing and Praying, as too many do, it is as if a Tree should Value itself on being water’d and putting forth Leaves, tho’ it never produc’d any Fruit.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Love your Enemies, for they tell you your Faults.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: The Way to see by Faith, is to shut the Eye of Reason: The Morning Daylight appears plainer when you put out your Candle.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: That Being, who gave me existence, and through almost threescore years has been continually showering his favors upon me, whose very chastisements have been blessings to me ; can I doubt that he loves me? And, if he loves me, can I doubt that he will go on to take care of me, not only here but hereafter? This to some may seem presumption ; to me it appears the best grounded hope ; hope of the future built on experience of the past.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Idleness and Pride Tax with a heavier Hand than Kings and Parliaments; If we can get rid of the former we may easily bear the Latter.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: I think the best way of doing good to the poor, is not making them easy in poverty, but leading or driving them out of it.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin
quote.reference: On the Price of Corn and Management of the Poor (29 November 1766)

quote.text: But your Squabbles about a Bishop I wish to see speedily ended. ... Each Party abuses the other, the Profane and the Infidel believe both sides, and enjoy the Fray; the Reputation of Religion in general suffers, and its enemies are ready to say, not what was said in the primitive Times, Behold how these Christians love one another, but, Mark how these Christians hate one another! Indeed when religious People quarrel about Religion, or hungry People about their Victuals, it looks as if they had not much of either among them.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: They who can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety, deserve neither liberty nor safety.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin
quote.reference: Memoirs of the life and writings of Benjamin Franklin (1818)

quote.text: We hear of the conversion of water into wine at the marriage in Cana as of a miracle. But this conversion is, through the goodness of God, made every day before our eyes. Behold the rain which descends from heaven upon our vineyards; there it enters the roots of the vines, to be changed into wine; a constant proof that God loves us, and loves to see us happy. The miracle in question was only performed to hasten the operation, under circumstances of present necessity, which required it.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: All Wars are Follies, very expensive, and very mischievous ones. When will Mankind be convinced of this, and agree to settle their Differences by Arbitration? Were they to do it, even by the Cast of a Dye, it would be better than by Fighting and destroying each other.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: There never was a good war or a bad peace.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: I wish the Bald Eagle had not been chosen as the representative of our country; he is a bird of bad moral character; like those among men who live by sharping and robbing, he is generally poor, and often very lousy. The turkey is a much more respectable bird.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Eat not to Dulness. Drink not to Elevation.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Speak not but what may benefit others or your self. Avoid trifling Conversation.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Let all your Things have their Places. Let each part of your Business have its Time.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Resolve to perform what you ought. Perform without fail what you resolve.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Make no Expense but to do good to others or yourself; i.e. Waste nothing.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Lose no Time. Be always employ'd in something useful. Cut off all unnecessary actions.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Use no hurtful Deceit. Think innocently and justly; and, if you speak, speak accordingly.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Wrong none, by doing Injuries or omitting the Benefits that are your Duty.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Avoid Extremes. Forbear resenting Injuries so much as you think they deserve.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Tolerate no Uncleanliness in Body, Clothes, or Habitation.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin

quote.text: Be not disturbed at Trifles, or at Accidents common or unavoidable.
quote.author: Benjamin Franklin
